senses.de: A line or small fold in cloth, skin, or paper, made when it is squeezed or after it has been used a lot.
senses.ex: The old man's face was full of wrinkles.

Tips.title: Visual Description
Tips.description: Use 'wrinkle' to describe visible lines that suggest age or use.
Tips.example: Her grandmother's hands were etched with wrinkles.

Tips.title: Metaphorical Use
Tips.description: Metaphorically, 'wrinkle' can imply a complication or problem in plans.
Tips.example: A sudden storm added a wrinkle to their picnic plans.

Tips.title: Negative Connotation
Tips.description: 'Wrinkle' often has a negative connotation when describing appearance.
Tips.example: He was self-conscious about the wrinkles in his suit.

senses.de: To become or make something full of lines or small folds. Also, to show that you are unhappy or thinking hard, by moving your forehead into lines or small folds.
senses.ex: She wrinkled her brow in concentration.

Tips.title: Emotion Indicator
Tips.description: Use 'wrinkle' as a verb to indicate confusion, worry, or concentration.
Tips.example: Confused, Marty wrinkled his forehead, trying to understand the riddle.

Tips.title: Momentary Action
Tips.description: As a verb, 'wrinkle' suggests a temporary change in appearance.
Tips.example: She wrinkled her nose in disgust at the smell.

senses.de: A new idea or method that is different from and better than existing ideas or methods.
senses.ex: She put a new wrinkle into the process to increase efficiency.

Tips.title: Positive Innovation
Tips.description: A 'wrinkle' can suggest a clever or positive improvement.
Tips.example: Adding an app was the latest wrinkle in the company's service.

Tips.title: Informal Enhancement
Tips.description: Often used informally to suggest something makes an aspect better.
Tips.example: He brought a new wrinkle to the game with his unpredictable strategy.

Tips.title: Creativity Context
Tips.description: Use this meaning to praise creativity or out-of-the-box thinking.
Tips.example: Her new wrinkle on the project impressed her employers.

Crease.wordDefinition:
The words crease and wrinkle both refer to lines or folds on a surface, but they can be used in slightly different ways.

A crease usually refers to a sharp, well-defined line, like the fold in a piece of paper or a garment. For example, you might say that you ironed out the creases in your shirt before going to work.

So, while both words describe lines or folds, crease is often used to talk about more sharply defined lines, while wrinkle can describe more gradual or subtle lines.

Crinkle.wordDefinition:
The words crinkle and wrinkle both refer to when something has folds or creases on its surface.

However, crinkle is used when the folds or creases are small and happen in a regular pattern, like crinkled paper. Wrinkle is used when the folds or creases are larger and happen in an irregular pattern, like wrinkled skin.

Crinkle is applicable to things that have small, regular folds or creases, like crinkled hair or crinkled paper, while wrinkle is applicable to things that have larger, irregular folds or creases, like wrinkled clothing or wrinkled skin.

Fold.wordDefinition:
Fold refers to a deliberate crease made in something, such as folding a piece of paper in half. Wrinkle refers to a line or crease caused by something being pressed or squeezed together, such as the wrinkles that form on a shirt after it's been packed away for a while.

Fold is applicable when you intentionally create a crease or bend in something, while wrinkle is applicable when a crease or fold appears naturally or unintentionally as a result of pressure or compression.

Furrow.wordDefinition:
A furrow is a deep groove or trench in the ground, typically made by a plow or cultivator. In a figurative sense, furrow can also mean a deep line or crevice on someone's face, usually caused by aging or stress.

Furrow is used for deep lines or grooves, while wrinkle is used for small creases or ridges. Furrow is commonly used to describe the lines on someone's forehead, while wrinkle describes the lines around someone's eyes or mouth.

Groove.wordDefinition:
A groove is a long, narrow cut or depression in a surface.

It can also refer to a rhythmic and repeated pattern in music. Grooves are typically found in objects such as vinyl records, wood, concrete, or metal.

In summary, grooves are shallow cuts usually found on non-biological objects, while wrinkles are folds typically found on biological surfaces.

Line.wordDefinition:
Line generally refers to a straight, narrow mark or stroke, whereas the word wrinkle refers to a crease or fold, usually found on the skin or fabric.

In terms of their applications, line can refer to a variety of things such as the lines on a piece of notebook paper, a line of text in a book or website, or a line of people waiting for something.

Line is a more general term that can refer to many different kinds of lines, whereas wrinkle is a more specific term applied only to creases or folds.

Ridge.wordDefinition:
A ridge is a long, narrow elevation or strip of elevated land or rock, while a wrinkle is a small crease or crumple on a surface such as cloth or skin.

Ridges are usually found in landscapes such as mountains, hills or valleys, and are formed by geological movements or erosion.

In summary, ridges are natural or man-made elevations, while wrinkles are small creases on surfaces such as clothes or skin.

Ruck.wordDefinition:
Ruck refers to a fold or crease in something, typically in fabric or a surface.

Essentially, ruck refers to a more general crease or fold in an object, while wrinkle describes a specific type of crease in the skin.

quotes.Text: As far as vanity and wrinkles and things like that, that's a part of life I don't worry about. I put on creams, you know, but don't go mad, and I don't have any kind of treatments. I just live a healthy lifestyle. And staying happy, not getting negative and angry, I think that helps, looking at the positive of everything.
quotes.Title: American Model
quotes.Name: Jerry Hall

quotes.Text: A lot of mainstream photographers seem not to think about what they're doing or feel any responsibility toward anything. By the time they're done, the models don't have any trace of themselves left. This thing about looking young with no wrinkles or expression is all so boring, really.
quotes.Title: German Photographer
quotes.Name: Peter Lindbergh

quotes.Text: I have had wrinkles on my forehead and my smile line since I was a kid. I see them in my own kids. I know what they're going to look like. So it's kind of like that's my personality. I feel the older you get, too, the more confident you become just in your own skin.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Faith Hill

quotes.Text: Between work and the kids, I never see anyone anymore. I mean, when I first met with ABC last spring, and they asked me what I'd been doing lately, I said: 'Gee, I have two kids. I'm usually covered with food, wrinkled and feel guilty all the time.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Felicity Huffman

quotes.Text: As much as I loathe this aging thing, I'm beginning to recognize that I am now a healthier person in terms of self-worth and knowing who I am and where I fit in the world. That's been a good trade-off for the wrinkles.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Patty Duke

quotes.Text: Getting older is baggage for so many people but I don't spend time on things I can't control. Wrinkles don't scare me; they're a part of life, and I will and do embrace them, but I look at surgery, and that scares me.
quotes.Title: American Model
quotes.Name: Christy Turlington

quotes.Text: Older women know who they are, and that makes them more beautiful than younger ones. I like to see a face with some character. I want to see lines. I want to see wrinkles.
quotes.Title: British Actor
quotes.Name: Naveen Andrews

quotes.Text: If I were afraid of wrinkles, I'd probably be hiding in a cupboard, because I have a lot of them.
quotes.Title: English Psychologist
quotes.Name: Susie Orbach

quotes.Text: There is nothing more beautiful than personality wrinkles.
quotes.Title: New Zealander Designer
quotes.Name: Emilia Wickstead

quotes.Text: Age does not bring you wisdom, age brings you wrinkles.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Estelle Getty
